channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: After his parents' divorce, a guidance counselor's kindness left a lasting mark
item.description: Life was turbulent for Patrick Furlong after his parents divorced when he was in 8th grade. His father left, so he needed to navigate daily routines without a paternal influence in his life.

item.title: How one Canadian's misplaced signature caused a diplomatic incident at the end of WWII
item.description: On Sept. 2, 1945, the Japanese and the Allies gathered to mark the official end of WWII. The process went smoothly until Col. Lawrence Cosgrave signed his name on the wrong line.

item.title: The novel 'Buckeye' explores forgiveness, war and a forbidden kiss
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to author Patrick Ryan about his new novel, Buckeye.

item.title: What to know about Bolsonaro's trial tomorrow in Brazil
item.description: The trial of the former far right president of Brazil begins Tuesday. The country's highest court has seen evidence and heard from witness that the ex-leader attempted a coup to stay in power in 2022.

item.title: The federal government is on track to shed 300,000 workers by the end of 2025
item.description: The federal government is on track to shed 300,000 workers by the end of the year. The Trump administration says it's an opportunity to improve efficiency. Many others fear a brain drain.

item.title: This album of songs for Gaza is in Yiddish, a language nearly eradicated by genocide
item.description: People are responding to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza in many ways. Earlier this month, a fundraising album of songs for Gaza was released in Yiddish, a language nearly eradicated through genocide.

item.title: Giraffes aren't just one species â€” they're four
item.description: We're used to thinking of giraffes as one species. Turns out, there are actually four distinct species of the world's tallest mammal.

item.title: Catholic congregations consider increasing security after Minneapolis shooting
item.description: Should churches have active shooter drills or armed ushers? Those are some of the measures under consideration after a shooting at a church in Minneapolis on Aug. 27.

item.title: Naomi Osaka and Coco Gauff meet again, on the court at the U.S. Open
item.description: Coco Gauff and Naomi Osaka faced off in the U.S. Open, a place they have a history with, together. In 2019, Osaka invited a teary Gauff to do a postgame interview with her.

item.title: Trump questions COVID-19 vaccines
item.description: President Trump has called on pharmaceutical companies to justify the success of drugs and vaccines used to fight COVID-19. Trump himself hailed the vaccines as a "modern-day miracle" back in 2020.
